Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Chemical Sentinel--A Mass Spectrometer Payload for AUV Gliders
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI requests funding to develop an ultra-compact mass for high-endurance operation onboard an AUV glider. The mass spectrometer will be optimized for operation aboard an AUV glider and will be capable of identifying and quantifying atmospheric, geologic, and biologically derived gases (methane, nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, sulfides, etc.) as well as many anthropogenic pollutants at levels down to parts-per-billion. It will fit within a glider payload volume and operate at low.

In-situ operation of these mass spectrometers onboard multiple AUV gliders will enable synoptic assessment of transient chemical phenomena such as deep-water upwelling, greenhouse gas cycling, red tides, and pulsed releases of chemicals caused by seismic events, storms, or human activity. As proof-of-concept the PI will integrate this mass spectrometer aboard a Slocum electric glider to characterize and persistently monitor water column chemistry in Massachusetts coastal waters and near the New England Shelf Break. This work will leverage the PI?s ongoing research in instrumentation development, autonomous robotics, and real-time environmental monitoring.

The objectives of this proposal are to: 1) Develop a cost-effective MS-glider technology for measuring dissolved gas variability relating to biogeochemical cycling of nitrogen, oxygen, and carbon in the subsurface marine water column; 2) Demonstrate this technology via deployments in coastal New England environments, then in long-range transects off the Atlantic shelf break, thereby validating a new means of observation for NSF?s OOI and other ocean observation programs; and 3) Integrate this research program into broad-based student curricula to promote engineering and science literacy.

Broader Impacts:

The proposed education program will provide exciting learning experiences for students from Middle school ages to graduate school. Today's students are often turned on by hands-on engineering projects and opportunities to analyze near-realtime data streams. This project offers both, plus avenues to introduce students to field work and sea expeditions. The PI is well situated to integrate his research into broad-based educational programs. The PI intends to provide broad-based exposure to STEM curricula and active learning experiences for students ranging from 8th graders, to high school, undergraduate and graduate levels. One of the most notable aspects of the proposal, in terms of the broader impacts, is Camilli's plan to work closely with schools that serve economically disadvantaged and underrepresented students at the middle or high school level. By supporting the 'teach the teacher' approach for the high school program, the PI will extend his reach to bring high quality STEM education to more students more consistently than he can do on his own. The PI will also provide education and training activities for undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER Award supported the development and successful open ocean operation of new class of autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV), Sentinel, that is This is equipped with an ultra-low power mass spectrometer. The Sentinel mass spectrometer is the lowest power mass spectrometer in the world. Sentinel's entire vehicle and payload system operates on approximately 10W total (roughly the same power demand as an i-Pad), weighs 85 kg in air, is 2.5 meters long, and is capable of operation to 1,000 m water depth.  These capabilities enable long-range unattended operation for in-situ observation of dissolved gases and pollutants in the subsea marine environment.

In 2012 the initial mass spectrometer prototype was used on an oceanographic expedition in the southern  Aegean Sea and led to the discovery of a new type of  seafloor pools (similar to brine pools) containing highly enriched in carbon dioxide. Subsequent investigations of the site discovered never-before identified chemolithotrophic microbes that are able to fix carbon without the benefit of photosynthesis.  In 2015 the Sentinel glider was field tested at Scott Reef, in the Timor Sea and demonstrated automated mission re-planning, enabling the vehicle to operate in close proximity to reef obstructions despite being in a high current area. In 2016 the Sentinel glider with its fully integrated mass spectrometer payload was successfully demonstrated in the Santa Barbara basin.  During these 2016 operations the Sentinel prototype successfully located and characterized water column hydrocarbon anomalies associated with naturally occurring seafloor cold seeps. In addition to its utility as a pollution response tool, Sentinel is now being used as a NASA testbed to develop advanced types of autonomy for robotic probes to explore the icy worlds of Europa, Titan, and Enceladus.

This NSF CAREER Award also supported research experience for postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students, including participation in eight oceanographic expeditions, which resulted in numerous peer reviewed publications and presentations at scientific conferences by these students. This CAREER award also enabled the PI to serve as an advisor for high school robotics clubs and student team participation in regional robotics competitions, as well as a guest lecturer for the Sea Education Association's undergraduate program  and serve as a guest scientist aboard the SSV/ CORWITH CRAMER. Additionally CAREER Award supported the Summer Introduction to Engineering and Scientific Research (SIESR) program, which has provided hands-on laboratory and field research experience to a total of 256 junior high and high school students. The junior high and high school students supported through this CAREER Award are generally from the Chester, PA and Dorchester-Roxbury, MA areas which are underserved communities. For example, approximately 80% of the 9th through 12th grade students in the Chester Upland School District are eligible for a free lunch due to family poverty and the high school graduation rate is typically below 50%. In comparison, there has been a 100% retention and graduation rate among Chester HS student who participate in the SIESR program. Of the SIESR students who have graduated high school, more than half of these students have gone onto college, with many receiving scholarships (including three Gates Millenium Scholars), and one student who served as a White House Intern for the Obama administration.  This past year the first SIESR student graduated from college and is now pursuing a masters degree in education.
